elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0100">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">ORTEP view of the asymmetric unit of (a) <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and (b) <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity Albeit there is no covalent interaction between the cobalt centers and the metalloligands, there exists extensive hydrogen bonding (H bonding) interactions between the cobalt coordinated water molecules and the metalloligands like that observed in the case of [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>2[MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L″]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:cross-ref id="c0005" refid="h0365">[21h]</ce:cross-ref>. Thus Co1 coordinated O1W is hydrogen bonded with Mo2 oxo oxygen O8 (<ce:cross-ref id="c0010" refid="f0030">Fig. 6</ce:cross-ref>). It also shows H-bonding interaction with O21 of DMF solvent. The other symmetrically equivalent O1W<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) shows H-bonding interactions with O8 of one metalloligand and O21 of another DMF molecule.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00025" locator="gr5" xlink:href="pii:S0277538715003691/gr5" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  ORTEP view of the asymmetric unit of (a) 2 and (b) 3. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity Albeit there is no covalent interaction between the cobalt centers and the metalloligands, there exists extensive hydrogen bonding (H bonding) interactions between the cobalt coordinated water molecules and the metalloligands like that observed in the case of [Co(H2O)6]2+2[MoO2L"]-⋅3H2O [21h]. Thus Co1 coordinated O1W is hydrogen bonded with Mo2 oxo oxygen O8 (Fig. 6). It also shows H-bonding interaction with O21 of DMF solvent. The other symmetrically equivalent O1Wa (a =-x +1, -y, -z) shows H-bonding interactions with O8 of one metalloligand and O21 of another DMF molecule.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The complexes [Na2(H2O)(Mo2O5L2)] n , [M(H2O)6][Mo2O5L2]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (M=Co or Ni) and [Zn(MeOH)2(H2O)2(Mo2O5L2)⋅H2O] n  {LH2 =2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid} have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The cobalt, nickel and the zinc complexes on heating afford the corresponding nanostructured mixed metal oxide MMoO4 and MoO3 {M=Co or Ni or Zn}.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Sodium complex of a new metalloligand, [Na2(H2O)(Mo2O5L2)] n  (1) {LH2 =2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid} has been synthesized from the reaction of Na2MoO4⋅2H2O with LH2. The sodium complex on reaction with MCl2⋅6H2O {M=Co or Ni} affords [Co(H2O)6][Mo2O5L2]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (2), [Ni(H2O)6][Mo2O5L2]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (3), respectively and on reaction with ZnCl2⋅6H2O affords the zinc complex of the metalloligand, [Zn(MeOH)2(H2O)2(Mo2O5L2)⋅H2O] n  (4). The cobalt, nickel and the zinc complexes, 2, 3 and 4 on heating afford the corresponding nanostructured mixed metal oxide MMoO4 and MoO3 {M=Co or Ni or Zn}.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The mixed metal oxides are important material due to their unique catalytic activities , piezochromic behavior , ferroelectric , magnetic , semiconducting  and optical properties . Transition metal molybdates have been shown to be active catalysts for desulfurization , dehydrogenation  and selective oxidation . Nickel and cobalt molybdates have been shown to be effective in energy storage .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The mixed metal oxides are important material due to their unique catalytic activities , piezochromic behavior , ferroelectric , magnetic , semiconducting  and optical properties . Transition metal molybdates have been shown to be active catalysts for desulfurization , dehydrogenation  and selective oxidation . Nickel and cobalt molybdates have been shown to be effective in energy storage .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In a recent report it has been shown that nanocomposite of CoMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and carbon nanotubes have good capacitance . In another recent report it has been shown that, nanorods of MMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co, Ni) have electrochemical lithium storage capacity and are potential cathode materials for lithium ion batteries . Zinc molybdate is a semiconducting material. Also, ZnMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> can be used as battery electrode and for drug delivery . It may be noted that, reports on nanostructured mixed metal oxides of molybdenum are limited because the traditional solid state synthesis of mixed oxides is very difficult .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In a recent report it has been shown that nanocomposite of CoMoO4 and carbon nanotubes have good capacitance . In another recent report it has been shown that, nanorods of MMoO4 (M=Co, Ni) have electrochemical lithium storage capacity and are potential cathode materials for lithium ion batteries . Zinc molybdate is a semiconducting material. Also, ZnMoO4 can be used as battery electrode and for drug delivery . It may be noted that, reports on nanostructured mixed metal oxides of molybdenum are limited because the traditional solid state synthesis of mixed oxides is very difficult .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">It is envisaged that, hererobimetallic complexes can be used as, single-source precursors for multimetallic oxides. Normally in the traditional solid state synthesis of such mixed metal oxides, high temperature is required and control over the composition of the mixed metal oxides is very difficult .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is envisaged that, hererobimetallic complexes can be used as, single-source precursors for multimetallic oxides. Normally in the traditional solid state synthesis of such mixed metal oxides, high temperature is required and control over the composition of the mixed metal oxides is very difficult .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">One of the best routes to hererobimetallic complexes is the use of a metal complex having free Lewis basic sites, known as metalloligand, for binding the second metal ion. The design and synthesis of metalloligand for binding other metal has drawn extensive attention due to their potential applications in catalysis, magnetic, optical and electronic properties . In recent years many coordination compounds containing cationic or anionic complex moiety have been synthesized which on further reaction with other metal complexes or metal ions form one-, two- and three-dimensional polymeric systems . Carboxylate-bridged heteronuclear transition metal complexes containing multidentate ligands have been investigated with reference to their role in biology and other areas . High-valent dioxo and trioxo molybdenum complexes of carboxylic acid based ligands are excellent building block due to their capability of formation of heterometallic compounds with higher order topological architecture . Molybdenum(VI) complexes containing the cis-[MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> core have been extensively studied in recent years due to their applications in biological, and oxo-transfer reactions, epoxidation, and numerous oxidation processes . We have been interested in the synthesis and structure of molybdenum containing metalloligands and their transition metal and main group metal complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: One of the best routes to hererobimetallic complexes is the use of a metal complex having free Lewis basic sites, known as metalloligand, for binding the second metal ion. The design and synthesis of metalloligand for binding other metal has drawn extensive attention due to their potential applications in catalysis, magnetic, optical and electronic properties . In recent years many coordination compounds containing cationic or anionic complex moiety have been synthesized which on further reaction with other metal complexes or metal ions form one-, two- and three-dimensional polymeric systems . Carboxylate-bridged heteronuclear transition metal complexes containing multidentate ligands have been investigated with reference to their role in biology and other areas . High-valent dioxo and trioxo molybdenum complexes of carboxylic acid based ligands are excellent building block due to their capability of formation of heterometallic compounds with higher order topological architecture . Molybdenum(VI) complexes containing the cis-[MoO2]2+ core have been extensively studied in recent years due to their applications in biological, and oxo-transfer reactions, epoxidation, and numerous oxidation processes . We have been interested in the synthesis and structure of molybdenum containing metalloligands and their transition metal and main group metal complexes .

elements.clean_text: Here in we report synthesis and structure of sodium, cobalt, nickel, and zinc complexes, of the metalloligand, [Mo2O5L2]2- {LH2 =2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid}, [Na2(H2O)(Mo2O5L2)] n  (1), [Co(H2O)6][Mo2O5L2]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (2), [Ni(H2O)6][Mo2O5L2]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (3), and [Zn(MeOH)2(H2O)2(Mo2O5L2)⋅H2O] n  (4).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">All the chemicals used were reagent grade products. The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR (400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz) spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance II spectrometer. The <ce:sup loc="pre">23</ce:sup>Na and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz) NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance II spectrometer (<ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H frequency: 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz). Elemental analyses were performed using Perkin–Elmer C, H, N, analyzer model 2400. The IR spectra were recorded on a Parkin–Elmer model 883 spectrometer. UV–Vis spectra were recorded in solution on a Shimadzu model UV-1601 spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was done by using Cu Kα radiation on a Bruker D8 advance X-ray diffractometer. Thermo gravimetric analyses were performed on a Perkin–Elmer Diamond Pyris TG/DTA analyzer in air. The HRMS of the newly synthesized ligand was recorded on Waters TOF MS in ESI+ mode in methanol–water mixture.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

All the chemicals used were reagent grade products. The 1H NMR (400MHz) spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance II spectrometer. The 23Na and 13C (100MHz) NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance II spectrometer (1H frequency: 400MHz). Elemental analyses were performed using Perkin-Elmer C, H, N, analyzer model 2400. The IR spectra were recorded on a Parkin-Elmer model 883 spectrometer. UV-Vis spectra were recorded in solution on a Shimadzu model UV-1601 spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was done by using Cu Kα radiation on a Bruker D8 advance X-ray diffractometer. Thermo gravimetric analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Diamond Pyris TG/DTA analyzer in air. The HRMS of the newly synthesized ligand was recorded on Waters TOF MS in ESI+ mode in methanol-water mixture.

To this was added 40% aqueous formaldehyde (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL; 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and the solution was stirred for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of ligand, 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid (LH2)

Glycine (1.50g; 20mmol) was dissolved in water (15mL). To this was added 40% aqueous formaldehyde (8mL; 100mmol) and the solution was stirred for 20min. To this was added an ethanolic solution (20mL) of 4-hydroxy-3-tert-butylanisole (1.80g; 10mmol) drop wise. After that the reaction mixture was heated for 8h on an oil bath at 70°C. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and allowed to stand overnight. The white precipitated ligand was filtered and washed with water and hexane and finally dried in vaccuo. Yield: 2.34g, 87%. 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3, ppm): 1.35 (s, 9H), 3.62 (s, 2H), 3.73 (s, 3H), 4.09 (s, 2H), 6.32 (s, 1H), 6.75 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (100MHz, CDCl3, ppm): δ =29.5, 34.8, 51.8, 53.1, pl.6, 108.3, 113.1, 118.9, 139.7, 146.3, 153.3, 173.9; ESI-HRMS: m/z =268.1586 [M+H]+ Calculated (C14H21NO4)=268.1549; IR (KBr): ν (cm-1)=782, 804, 867, 1061, 1202, 1434, 1460, 1601, 1719, 2947, 3443.

Synthesis of the complex [Na2(H2O)(Mo2O5L2)] n  (1)

An aqueous solution (1mL) of Na2MoO4⋅2H2O (0.097g, 0.4mmol) was added to the methanolic solution (10mL) of LH2 (0.107g, 0.4mmol) and pH was adjusted at about 5 using dilute hydrochloric acid. Then the reaction mixture was stirred for about 5h. After that the clear solution was allowed to stand for crystallization. Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained within 1week. Yield: 82%. Anal. Calc. for C28H40N2O14Mo2Na2 (Mol. wt. 866.48): C, 38.81; H, 4.65; N, 3.23. Found: C, 38.48; H, 4.62; N, 3.34%. 1H NMR (400MHz, CD3OD, ppm): 1.36 (s, 9H), 3.04 (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H), 4.45 (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H), 3.49 (d, J =16.0Hz, 1H), 3.58 (d, J =16.0Hz, 1H), 3.70 (s, 3H), 6.54 (d, J =4Hz, 1H), 6.73 (d, J =4Hz, 1H); 23Na NMR (CD3OD, ppm) [reference NaCl (δ =0ppm)]: -3.74; IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) 763, 881, 924, 1075, 1143, 1214, 1250, 1384, 1434, 1467, 1601, 1622, 2951, 3226, 3330; UV-Vis: λ max (ε)=369nm (4934), 292nm (7969), 224nm (39460).

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

Single crystal X-ray data of 1, 2, 3 and 4 were collected on Bruker Smart APEX system that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The structure was solved by direct method and refined by least square method on F 2 employing WinGx  package and the relevant programs {shelx-97  and ortep-3 } implemented therein. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms on C-atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st050">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st055">Synthesis and characterization of 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">During our previous studies on alkali metal complexes of molybdenum containing metalloligands we used the tridentate organic ligands, {(3,5-di-<ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)amino}acetic acid for the construction of metalloligand and obtained a tetranuclear sodium complex . In the present case we have varied the substituent on the phenyl ring keeping the amino acid part same and used 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid for the synthesis of the metalloligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization of 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid

During our previous studies on alkali metal complexes of molybdenum containing metalloligands we used the tridentate organic ligands, {(3,5-di-tert-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)amino}acetic acid for the construction of metalloligand and obtained a tetranuclear sodium complex . In the present case we have varied the substituent on the phenyl ring keeping the amino acid part same and used 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid for the synthesis of the metalloligand.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The ligand 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid has been synthesized form the reaction of glycine with 4-hydroxy-3-<ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butylanisole in the presence of aqueous formaldehyde. The ligand has been characterized by the elemental analyses, mass spectrometry, IR, UV–Vis, and <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectroscopy. The elemental analyses and mass spectral measurement agree well with the composition. Spectral measurements are in agreement with the proposed structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The ligand 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid has been synthesized form the reaction of glycine with 4-hydroxy-3-tert-butylanisole in the presence of aqueous formaldehyde. The ligand has been characterized by the elemental analyses, mass spectrometry, IR, UV-Vis, and 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy. The elemental analyses and mass spectral measurement agree well with the composition. Spectral measurements are in agreement with the proposed structure.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis, characterization and solution properties of the complexes

The sodium complex [Na2(H2O)(Mo2O5L2)] n  (1) has been synthesized from the reaction of LH2 with sodium molybdate in aqueous methanol and after that other three heterobimetallic complexes (2, 3, and 4) have been synthesized from the reaction of the complex 1 with the metal chloride in aqueous methanol. All the complexes have been characterized by IR, UV-Vis, 1H NMR (complex 1 and 4), 23Na NMR (complex 1) spectroscopy and single crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The IR spectra of the complexes show two strong bands at ca. 924cm-1 and at ca. 840cm-1 due to symmetric and antisymmetric cis-Mo=(O)2 stretch and a band at ca. 764cm-1 due to Mo-O-Mo stretch and thus it clearly shows the presence of [MoO2(μ-O)MoO2] moiety . The UV-Vis spectra of the complexes show a strong band at ca. 370nm due to ligand-to-metal charge-transfer transition along with internal transitions of the ligand.

The signal for the –CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> protons of the OMe group appears at <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> 3.69<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (s, 3H). The signal for aromatic protons appear at <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> 6.54<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (d, <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Hz, 1H) and at <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> 6.72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (d, <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Hz, 1H). The appearance of the signals for the methylene protons as diasterotopic protons clearly shows that, in solution the ligand remains bonded with the molybdenum center. The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H sepctral features are similar to those observed earlier in the case of {[Na<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>L′<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} [L′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(3,5-di-<ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)aminoacetate] . The <ce:sup loc="pre">23</ce:sup>Na NMR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a single broad signal at <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> −3.73<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (relative to NaCl as an external reference). elements.clean_text: The 1H NMR spectrum of 1 [CD3OD] shows signals at δ 1.36ppm (s, 9H) due to methyl protons of tert-butyl group. The benzylic -CH2 proton signals appear at δ 3.57ppm (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H) and at δ 4.45ppm (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H). The signals for -CH2 protons, adjacent to the -COOH group appear at δ 3.04ppm (d, J =16.0Hz, 1H) and at δ 3.49ppm (d, J =16.0Hz, 1H). The signal for the -CH3 protons of the OMe group appears at δ 3.69ppm (s, 3H). The signal for aromatic protons appear at δ 6.54ppm (d, J =2.8Hz, 1H) and at δ 6.72ppm (d, J =2.8Hz, 1H). The appearance of the signals for the methylene protons as diasterotopic protons clearly shows that, in solution the ligand remains bonded with the molybdenum center. The 1H sepctral features are similar to those observed earlier in the case of {[Na4(H2O)4(μ-H2O)2]  ⊂  [Mo2O5L'2]2} [L'=(3,5-di-tert-butyl-2-hydroxybenzyl)aminoacetate] . The 23Na NMR spectrum of 1 shows a single broad signal at δ -3.73ppm (relative to NaCl as an external reference). This clearly shows that the coordinated nature of the sodium is maintained even in solution and that all the sodium ions are in a similar chemical environment. The observed low-field position of the 23Na NMR signal, with respect to the NaCl reference, indicates the existence of strong interactions between the sodium ions and between sodium and molybdenum, even in solution.

Asymmetric unit contains one molybdenum center (Mo1) coordinated to one organic ligand via one nitrogen (N1) and a carboxylate oxygen (O6) and a phenolic oxygen (O4), two oxo groups (O1 and O2), one oxygen with half occupancy (O3), and a sodium center (Na1) coordinated to oxo oxygen, O2 and one water molecule (O1W) cooedinated to the sodium center with half occupancy (

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of the compound [Na2(H2O)(Mo2O5L2)] n  (1)

Single crystals of 1, suitable for X-ray diffraction, were grown from an aqueous methanolic solution (1:3). Information concerning X-ray data collection and structure refinement of this compound is summarized in  . The compound crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. Asymmetric unit contains one molybdenum center (Mo1) coordinated to one organic ligand via one nitrogen (N1) and a carboxylate oxygen (O6) and a phenolic oxygen (O4), two oxo groups (O1 and O2), one oxygen with half occupancy (O3), and a sodium center (Na1) coordinated to oxo oxygen, O2 and one water molecule (O1W) cooedinated to the sodium center with half occupancy ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The molybdenum centers in [LMoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-O)MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are in distorted octahedral coordination environment and the coordination geometry around the molybdenum centers are similar to that observed earlier  (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The metalloligand binds two symmetrically equivalent sodium ions Na1 by two symmetrically equivalent oxo oxygens O2. In addition, two more sodium ions are bound to the metalloligand via symmetrically equivalent carboxylate oxygens, O5 and O6. Thus, each of the metalloligand binds four sodium atoms. Each of the sodium atoms are bonded to another metalloligand and thus form a polymeric chain. The water oxygen bridges two sodium ions. Each of the sodium ions are coordinated to oxo oxygen O2 of one metalloligand, carboxylate oxygens O5 and O6 of second metalloligand and carboxylate oxygen O6 of third metalloligand. Thus, each sodium ion is coordinated to three metalloligands. In addition, two sodium ions are bridged by one water molecule. Thus each sodium ion is in a highly distorted square pyramidal coordination environment (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). In solid state, the four sodium ions and four oxygens form eight member rings and these sodium ions form a double helical chain with a pitch length of 8.003<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å which is equal to the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis and the chain grows along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The molybdenum centers in [LMoO2(μ-O)MoO2L]2- are in distorted octahedral coordination environment and the coordination geometry around the molybdenum centers are similar to that observed earlier  ( ). The metalloligand binds two symmetrically equivalent sodium ions Na1 by two symmetrically equivalent oxo oxygens O2. In addition, two more sodium ions are bound to the metalloligand via symmetrically equivalent carboxylate oxygens, O5 and O6. Thus, each of the metalloligand binds four sodium atoms. Each of the sodium atoms are bonded to another metalloligand and thus form a polymeric chain. The water oxygen bridges two sodium ions. Each of the sodium ions are coordinated to oxo oxygen O2 of one metalloligand, carboxylate oxygens O5 and O6 of second metalloligand and carboxylate oxygen O6 of third metalloligand. Thus, each sodium ion is coordinated to three metalloligands. In addition, two sodium ions are bridged by one water molecule. Thus each sodium ion is in a highly distorted square pyramidal coordination environment ( ). In solid state, the four sodium ions and four oxygens form eight member rings and these sodium ions form a double helical chain with a pitch length of 8.003Å which is equal to the crystallographic c axis and the chain grows along the crystallographic c axis ( ).

Crystal structure of the compounds [Co(H2O)6][(Mo2O5L2)]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (2), [Ni(H2O)6][(Mo2O5L2)]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (3)

Since [Co(H2O)6][(Mo2O5L2)]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (2) and [Ni(H2O)6][(Mo2O5L2)]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (3) are isostructural, details of the structural features of 2 only has been discussed. Both the complexes crystallize in triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . The ORTEP view of the asymmetric unit of 2 and 3 are shown in  . The asymmetric unit of the complexes consist of a dimeric metalloligand, [LMoO2(μ-O)MoO2L]2-, the structural features of which are very similar to those discussed above, two cobalt/nickel centers with half occupancy, each of which is coordinated to three water molecules and three solvent molecules of crystallization, two DMF and one water.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="pc-p1" view="all">Albeit there is no covalent interaction between the cobalt centers and the metalloligands, there exists extensive hydrogen bonding (H bonding) interactions between the cobalt coordinated water molecules and the metalloligands like that observed in the case of [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>2[MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L″]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . Thus Co1 coordinated O1W is hydrogen bonded with Mo2 oxo oxygen O8 (). It also shows H-bonding interaction with O21 of DMF solvent. The other symmetrically equivalent O1W<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup> (a<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) shows H-bonding interactions with O8 of one metalloligand and O21 of another DMF molecule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Albeit there is no covalent interaction between the cobalt centers and the metalloligands, there exists extensive hydrogen bonding (H bonding) interactions between the cobalt coordinated water molecules and the metalloligands like that observed in the case of [Co(H2O)6]2+2[MoO2L"]-⋅3H2O . Thus Co1 coordinated O1W is hydrogen bonded with Mo2 oxo oxygen O8 (). It also shows H-bonding interaction with O21 of DMF solvent. The other symmetrically equivalent O1Wa (a=-x +1, -y, -z) shows H-bonding interactions with O8 of one metalloligand and O21 of another DMF molecule.

The Co1 coordinated water molecules O3W and O3W<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup> shows H-bonding interactions with two Co2 coordinated water molecules O4W and Mo1 coordinated carboxylate oxygens O6 of two metalloligands. The Co2 coordinated water molecules O4W and O4W<ce:sup loc="post">b</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) show H-bonding interactions with Co1 coordinated two water molecules O3W and O3W<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup> of two [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions. In addition, these water molecules also show H-bonding interactions with Mo2 coordinated carboxylate oxygens O12 of two metalloligands. The Co2 coordinated water molecules O5W and O5W<ce:sup loc="post">b</ce:sup> are H-bonded with two DMF oxygens, O14 and Mo2 coordianted carboxylate oxygens O11 of two metalloligands. The two Co2 coordinated water molecules O6W and O6W<ce:sup loc="post">b</ce:sup> show H-bonding interactions with Mo1 oxo oxygens O2 of two metalloligands and DMF oxygens, O21. In addition the solvent water molecule O7W is H-bonded with carboxylate oxygens O6 and O11 of two metalloligands. Thus in solid state the compound forms a 1D H-bonded network, which extends along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (

The Co1 coordinated water molecules O3W and O3Wa shows H-bonding interactions with two Co2 coordinated water molecules O4W and Mo1 coordinated carboxylate oxygens O6 of two metalloligands. The Co2 coordinated water molecules O4W and O4Wb (b =-x, -y, -z) show H-bonding interactions with Co1 coordinated two water molecules O3W and O3Wa of two [Co(H2O)6]2+ ions. In addition, these water molecules also show H-bonding interactions with Mo2 coordinated carboxylate oxygens O12 of two metalloligands. The Co2 coordinated water molecules O5W and O5Wb are H-bonded with two DMF oxygens, O14 and Mo2 coordianted carboxylate oxygens O11 of two metalloligands. The two Co2 coordinated water molecules O6W and O6Wb show H-bonding interactions with Mo1 oxo oxygens O2 of two metalloligands and DMF oxygens, O21. In addition the solvent water molecule O7W is H-bonded with carboxylate oxygens O6 and O11 of two metalloligands. Thus in solid state the compound forms a 1D H-bonded network, which extends along the crystallographic a axis ( ).

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [Zn(MeOH)2(H2O)2(Mo2O5L2)⋅H2O] n  (4)

The complex crystallizes in triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . The asymmetric unit consists of the mtalloligand [LMoO2(μ-O)MoO2L]2- and two zinc atoms, with half occupancy each, coordinated to the two carboxylate oxygens of the metalloligand ( ). In addition, the zinc atoms are coordinated to one water and one methanol molecule each. In the full structure, the complex forms a 1D polymeric chain, which extends along crystallographic c axis. The coordination geometry and the structural features of the metalloligand are same as those observed for the structures of 1, 2 and 3. Each of the zinc atoms is in a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment and is coordinated to carboxylate oxygens of two metalloligands in a trans fashion and two water and two methanol molecules, which are also trans to each other. The zinc center Zn1 is coordinated to Mo1 coordinated carboxylate oxygens O8 and O8c (c =-x, -y +2, -z +1) of two metalloligands and two water molecules O1W and O1Wc and two methanol oxygens O10 and O10c. Similarly, Zn2 center is coordinated to Mo2 coordinated carboxylate oxygens O13 and O13d (d =-x, -y +2, -z) of two metalloligands, and water oxygens, O2W and O2Wd and methanol oxygens O15 and O15d ( ). The metalloligands bind the zinc centers in trans fashion and thus forms a zigzag 1D polymeric chain ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">In solid state there exists intra-chain H-bonding. For example, Zn1 coordinated two methanol OH (O10) shows H-bonding interactions with Zn1 coordinated carboxylate oxygen, O8 and oxo- oxygen O3 of two metalloligands. In addition the Zn1 coordinated water, O1W is H bonded with carboxylate oxygen O8. Similarly, Zn2 coordinated water, O2W and O2W<ce:sup loc="post">d</ce:sup> is hydrogen bonded with carboxylate oxygens O12 of two metalloligands and Zn2 coordinated methanol oxygen is H bonded with two oxo oxygens, O1 of two metalloligands. In addition there exists Inter-chain H-bonding in solid state. The Zn1 coordinated water molecules O1W and O1W<ce:sup loc="post">c</ce:sup> is H-bonded with oxo-oxygens O4 and nitrogens N1 of two different 1D chain. The H-bonded chain extends along crystallographic <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. Thus in solid state it forms a H-bonded 1D network and overall the complex forms a 2D network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>

In addition the Zn1 coordinated water, O1W is H bonded with carboxylate oxygen O8. Similarly, Zn2 coordinated water, O2W and O2Wd is hydrogen bonded with carboxylate oxygens O12 of two metalloligands and Zn2 coordinated methanol oxygen is H bonded with two oxo oxygens, O1 of two metalloligands. In addition there exists Inter-chain H-bonding in solid state. The Zn1 coordinated water molecules O1W and O1Wc is H-bonded with oxo-oxygens O4 and nitrogens N1 of two different 1D chain. The H-bonded chain extends along crystallographic b axis. Thus in solid state it forms a H-bonded 1D network and overall the complex forms a 2D network ( ).

<ce:section-title id="st080">Thermogravimetric analysis of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">We were interested in determining the efficacy of the newly synthesized complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> as the precursors for the synthesis of mixed metal oxides of cobalt and molybdenum and that of nickel and molybdenum and zinc and molybdenum. Thus the cobalt, nickel and zinc complexes were subjected to thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in order to determine the nature of the thermally decomposed product.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis of complexes 2, 3 and 4 

We were interested in determining the efficacy of the newly synthesized complexes 2, 3 and 4 as the precursors for the synthesis of mixed metal oxides of cobalt and molybdenum and that of nickel and molybdenum and zinc and molybdenum. Thus the cobalt, nickel and zinc complexes were subjected to thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in order to determine the nature of the thermally decomposed product.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The thermogravimetric analyses of complexes have been performed in air in the temperature range of 30–700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). The thermogram of the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows that it loses all the solvent molecules (two DMF and seven water molecules) below 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Between 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to about 630<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C it looses the organic ligand. Total weight loss from 100 to 630<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be associated with the loss of coordinated water molecules, DMF molecules and two organic ligands (weight loss: exptl. 67.66%, calcd. 70.82%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thermogravimetric analyses of complexes have been performed in air in the temperature range of 30-700°C (). The thermogram of the complex 2 shows that it loses all the solvent molecules (two DMF and seven water molecules) below 250°C. Between 250°C to about 630°C it looses the organic ligand. Total weight loss from 100 to 630°C can be associated with the loss of coordinated water molecules, DMF molecules and two organic ligands (weight loss: exptl. 67.66%, calcd. 70.82%).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0120" view="all">The residual weight, 32.34% (calcd. 29.18%) corresponds to mixed bimetallic oxide, CoMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. The thermal decomposition of the complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is similar to that observed for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The total weight loss from 100 to 550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be associated with the loss of coordinated water molecules, DMF molecules and two organic ligands (weight loss: exptl. 68.06%, calcd. 70.84%). The residual weight, 31.94% (calcd. 29.16%) corresponds to mixed bimetallic oxide, NiMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. The thermogram of the complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shows that it loses all the solvent molecules (water and methanol molecules) below 105<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. After that the loss of organic ligands starts. Total weight loss from 100 to 590<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be associated with the loss of coordinated solvent molecules and organic ligands. The residual weight, 26.52% corresponds to mixed bimetallic oxide, ZnMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The residual weight, 32.34% (calcd. 29.18%) corresponds to mixed bimetallic oxide, CoMoO4 and MoO3. The thermal decomposition of the complex 3 is similar to that observed for complex 2. The total weight loss from 100 to 550°C can be associated with the loss of coordinated water molecules, DMF molecules and two organic ligands (weight loss: exptl. 68.06%, calcd. 70.84%). The residual weight, 31.94% (calcd. 29.16%) corresponds to mixed bimetallic oxide, NiMoO4 and MoO3. The thermogram of the complex 4 shows that it loses all the solvent molecules (water and methanol molecules) below 105°C. After that the loss of organic ligands starts. Total weight loss from 100 to 590°C can be associated with the loss of coordinated solvent molecules and organic ligands. The residual weight, 26.52% corresponds to mixed bimetallic oxide, ZnMoO4 and MoO3.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The complexes, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were heated in a furnace at 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under air and the oxides were subjected to powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (). The XRD patterns were refined by Rietveld method using MAUD program . The diffractograms analyzed by Rietveld method of the decomposition product of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are given in , respectively. The diffractogram of the decomposition product of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows that it contains two phases, namely CoMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (JCPDS No. 08-9475) and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of CoMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is 65% and 35%, respectively (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">wp</ce:inf> (%)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.27 <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> (%)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.68). Similarly, the diffractogram of the decomposition product of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> shows that it contains two phases one is NiMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (JCPDS No. 33-0948) and other is MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of NiMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is 92% and 8%, respectively (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">wp</ce:inf> (%)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.31 <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> (%)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.66).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The complexes, 2, 3 and 4 were heated in a furnace at 700°C under air and the oxides were subjected to powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (). The XRD patterns were refined by Rietveld method using MAUD program . The diffractograms analyzed by Rietveld method of the decomposition product of 2, 3 and 4 are given in , respectively. The diffractogram of the decomposition product of 2 shows that it contains two phases, namely CoMoO4 (JCPDS No. 08-9475) and MoO3 (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of CoMoO4 and MoO3 is 65% and 35%, respectively (R wp (%)=6.27 R b (%)=3.68). Similarly, the diffractogram of the decomposition product of 3 shows that it contains two phases one is NiMoO4 (JCPDS No. 33-0948) and other is MoO3 (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of NiMoO4 and MoO3 is 92% and 8%, respectively (R wp (%)=5.31 R b (%)=3.66).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The diffractogram of the decomposition product of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shows that it contains two phases one is ZnMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (JCPDS No. 17-4340) and other is MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of ZnMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is 98.4% and 1.6%, respectively (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">wp</ce:inf> (%)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.96 <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">b</ce:inf> (%)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.80). The decomposed products were annealed at 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for two hours and the PXRD were recorded. The diffractograms were analyzed by Rietveld method. However, the weight percentage of MMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> {M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co, Ni or Zn} and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> did not show much change form those observed in the cases of as synthesized materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The diffractogram of the decomposition product of 4 shows that it contains two phases one is ZnMoO4 (JCPDS No. 17-4340) and other is MoO3 (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of ZnMoO4 and MoO3 is 98.4% and 1.6%, respectively (R wp (%)=14.96 R b (%)=9.80). The decomposed products were annealed at 700°C for two hours and the PXRD were recorded. The diffractograms were analyzed by Rietveld method. However, the weight percentage of MMoO4 {M=Co, Ni or Zn} and MoO3 did not show much change form those observed in the cases of as synthesized materials.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st085">Morphology of the decomposed products of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0135" view="all">The morphologies of the mixed metal oxides were studied by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). The mixture of CoMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is composed of block-shape particles with an average size of 128 to 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>a). The FESEM image (b) of NiMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> nanoparticles shows granular morphology with an average size of 45–120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The FESEM images of ZnMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (c) shows rod like morphology with an average width of 25–212<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. It has also been observed that nanorods are aggregated to form lumps. The EDX measurements clearly show the presence of Co/Ni/Zn, molybdenum and oxygen. The atomic ratio of molybdenum: Co/Ni/Zn was found to be approximately two in the EDX measurements.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Morphology of the decomposed products of complexes 2, 3 and 4 

The morphologies of the mixed metal oxides were studied by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). The mixture of CoMoO4 and MoO3 is composed of block-shape particles with an average size of 128 to 250nm ( a). The FESEM image (b) of NiMoO4 and MoO3 nanoparticles shows granular morphology with an average size of 45-120nm. The FESEM images of ZnMoO4 and MoO3 (c) shows rod like morphology with an average width of 25-212nm. It has also been observed that nanorods are aggregated to form lumps. The EDX measurements clearly show the presence of Co/Ni/Zn, molybdenum and oxygen. The atomic ratio of molybdenum: Co/Ni/Zn was found to be approximately two in the EDX measurements.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st090">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0140" view="all">In conclusion we have synthesized bimetallic complexes of sodium, cobalt, nickel and zinc using a molybdenum metalloligand. The complexes have been characterized structurally by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The cobalt, nickel and zinc complexes have been found to undergo thermal decomposition at 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to afford nanostructured mixture of MMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> {M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co, Ni, Zn}.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion we have synthesized bimetallic complexes of sodium, cobalt, nickel and zinc using a molybdenum metalloligand. The complexes have been characterized structurally by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The cobalt, nickel and zinc complexes have been found to undergo thermal decomposition at 700°C to afford nanostructured mixture of MMoO4 and MoO3 {M=Co, Ni, Zn}.

Synthesis of ligand, 2-(3-tert-butyl-2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzylamino) acetic acid (LH2)

Glycine (1.50g; 20mmol) was dissolved in water (15mL). To this was added 40% aqueous formaldehyde (8mL; 100mmol) and the solution was stirred for 20min. To this was added an ethanolic solution (20mL) of 4-hydroxy-3-tert-butylanisole (1.80g; 10mmol) drop wise. After that the reaction mixture was heated for 8h on an oil bath at 70°C. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and allowed to stand overnight. The white precipitated ligand was filtered and washed with water and hexane and finally dried in vaccuo. Yield: 2.34g, 87%. 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3, ppm): 1.35 (s, 9H), 3.62 (s, 2H), 3.73 (s, 3H), 4.09 (s, 2H), 6.32 (s, 1H), 6.75 (s, 1H); 13C NMR (100MHz, CDCl3, ppm): δ =29.5, 34.8, 51.8, 53.1, pl.6, 108.3, 113.1, 118.9, 139.7, 146.3, 153.3, 173.9; ESI-HRMS: m/z =268.1586 [M+H]+ Calculated (C14H21NO4)=268.1549; IR (KBr): ν (cm-1)=782, 804, 867, 1061, 1202, 1434, 1460, 1601, 1719, 2947, 3443.

Synthesis of the complex [Na2(H2O)(Mo2O5L2)] n  (1)

An aqueous solution (1mL) of Na2MoO4⋅2H2O (0.097g, 0.4mmol) was added to the methanolic solution (10mL) of LH2 (0.107g, 0.4mmol) and pH was adjusted at about 5 using dilute hydrochloric acid. Then the reaction mixture was stirred for about 5h. After that the clear solution was allowed to stand for crystallization. Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained within 1week. Yield: 82%. Anal. Calc. for C28H40N2O14Mo2Na2 (Mol. wt. 866.48): C, 38.81; H, 4.65; N, 3.23. Found: C, 38.48; H, 4.62; N, 3.34%. 1H NMR (400MHz, CD3OD, ppm): 1.36 (s, 9H), 3.04 (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H), 4.45 (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H), 3.49 (d, J =16.0Hz, 1H), 3.58 (d, J =16.0Hz, 1H), 3.70 (s, 3H), 6.54 (d, J =4Hz, 1H), 6.73 (d, J =4Hz, 1H); 23Na NMR (CD3OD, ppm) [reference NaCl (δ =0ppm)]: -3.74; IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) 763, 881, 924, 1075, 1143, 1214, 1250, 1384, 1434, 1467, 1601, 1622, 2951, 3226, 3330; UV-Vis: λ max (ε)=369nm (4934), 292nm (7969), 224nm (39460).

Synthesis of the complexes [Co(H2O)6][(Mo2O5L2)]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (2), [Ni(H2O)6][(Mo2O5L2)]⋅2DMF⋅H2O (3) and [Zn(MeOH)2(H2O)2(Mo2O5L2)⋅H2O] n  (4)

The aqueous solution of MCl2⋅6H2O {M=Co (2), Ni (3), Zn (4)} (1.2mmol) was added to the aqueous methanolic solution of 1 (0.4mmol) and the reaction mixture was stirred for about 2h at room temperature, after that it was filtered. In the case of zinc complex, orange-red crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained within 2-3weeks. However, in the cases of cobalt and nickel complexes, precipitates were obtained. The complexes were recrystallized from DMF and crystals, suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained within 2-3days. 2: Yield: 68%. Anal. Calc. for 2, C34H66N4O22Mo2Co (Mol. wt. 1133.71): C, 36.02; H, 5.87; N, 4.94. Found: C, 36.08; H, 5.62; N, 4.92%. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1)=775, 891, 928, 1060, 1146, 1212, 1242, 1388, 1430, 1457, 1596, 1654, 2954, 3430; UV-Vis: λ max (ε)=366nm (5426), 276nm (17003). 3: Yield: 69%. Anal. Calc. for 3, C34H66N4O22Mo2Ni (Mol. wt. 1133.47): C, 36.03; H, 5.87; N, 4.94. Found: C, 36.10; H, 5.92; N, 4.96%. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1)=765, 882, 926, 1062, 1146, 1212, 1239, 1388, 1430, 1467, 1600, 2958, 3369; UV-Vis: λ max (ε)=362nm (3983), 288nm (10282). 4: Yield: 52%. Anal. Calc. for 4, C30H52N2O18Mo2Zn (Mol. wt. 986.0): C, 36.54; H, 5.32; N, 2.84. Found: C, 36.58; H, 5.39; N, 2.79%. 1H NMR (400MHz, [D6] DMSO, ppm): 1.25 (s, 9H), 2.90 (d, J =16.0Hz, 1H), 4.0 (dd, J =16.0, 8.0Hz, 1H), 3.49 (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H), 4.16 (d, J =12.0Hz, 1H), 5.16 (br, s, 1H), 6.50 (br, s, 1H), 6.54 (br, s, 1H); IR (KBr): ν (cm-1)=764, 883, 924, 1063, 1145, 1213, 1234, 1388, 1429, 1467, 1602, 2959, 3242; UV-Vis: λ max (ε)=362nm (2636), 292nm (7142).

The diffractogram of the decomposition product of 4 shows that it contains two phases one is ZnMoO4 (JCPDS No. 17-4340) and other is MoO3 (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of ZnMoO4 and MoO3 is 98.4% and 1.6%, respectively (R wp (%)=14.96 R b (%)=9.80). The decomposed products were annealed at 700°C for two hours and the PXRD were recorded. The diffractograms were analyzed by Rietveld method. However, the weight percentage of MMoO4 {M=Co, Ni or Zn} and MoO3 did not show much change form those observed in the cases of as synthesized materials.

cln_elements.clean_text:
The thermogravimetric analyses of complexes have been performed in air in the temperature range of 30-700°C (). The thermogram of the complex 2 shows that it loses all the solvent molecules (two DMF and seven water molecules) below 250°C. Between 250°C to about 630°C it looses the organic ligand. Total weight loss from 100 to 630°C can be associated with the loss of coordinated water molecules, DMF molecules and two organic ligands (weight loss: exptl. 67.66%, calcd. 70.82%).

The complexes, 2, 3 and 4 were heated in a furnace at 700°C under air and the oxides were subjected to powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (). The XRD patterns were refined by Rietveld method using MAUD program . The diffractograms analyzed by Rietveld method of the decomposition product of 2, 3 and 4 are given in , respectively. The diffractogram of the decomposition product of 2 shows that it contains two phases, namely CoMoO4 (JCPDS No. 08-9475) and MoO3 (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of CoMoO4 and MoO3 is 65% and 35%, respectively (R wp (%)=6.27 R b (%)=3.68). Similarly, the diffractogram of the decomposition product of 3 shows that it contains two phases one is NiMoO4 (JCPDS No. 33-0948) and other is MoO3 (JCPDS No. 47-1320) where the weight percentage of NiMoO4 and MoO3 is 92% and 8%, respectively (R wp (%)=5.31 R b (%)=3.66).

Morphology of the decomposed products of complexes 2, 3 and 4 

The morphologies of the mixed metal oxides were studied by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). The mixture of CoMoO4 and MoO3 is composed of block-shape particles with an average size of 128 to 250nm ( a). The FESEM image (b) of NiMoO4 and MoO3 nanoparticles shows granular morphology with an average size of 45-120nm. The FESEM images of ZnMoO4 and MoO3 (c) shows rod like morphology with an average width of 25-212nm. It has also been observed that nanorods are aggregated to form lumps. The EDX measurements clearly show the presence of Co/Ni/Zn, molybdenum and oxygen. The atomic ratio of molybdenum: Co/Ni/Zn was found to be approximately two in the EDX measurements.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0100">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">ORTEP view of the asymmetric unit of (a) <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and (b) <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity Albeit there is no covalent interaction between the cobalt centers and the metalloligands, there exists extensive hydrogen bonding (H bonding) interactions between the cobalt coordinated water molecules and the metalloligands like that observed in the case of [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>2[MoO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L″]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:cross-ref id="c0005" refid="h0365">[21h]</ce:cross-ref>. Thus Co1 coordinated O1W is hydrogen bonded with Mo2 oxo oxygen O8 (<ce:cross-ref id="c0010" refid="f0030">Fig. 6</ce:cross-ref>). It also shows H-bonding interaction with O21 of DMF solvent. The other symmetrically equivalent O1W<ce:sup loc="post">a</ce:sup> (<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) shows H-bonding interactions with O8 of one metalloligand and O21 of another DMF molecule.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk00025" locator="gr5" xlink:href="pii:S0277538715003691/gr5" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  ORTEP view of the asymmetric unit of (a) 2 and (b) 3. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity Albeit there is no covalent interaction between the cobalt centers and the metalloligands, there exists extensive hydrogen bonding (H bonding) interactions between the cobalt coordinated water molecules and the metalloligands like that observed in the case of [Co(H2O)6]2+2[MoO2L"]-⋅3H2O [21h]. Thus Co1 coordinated O1W is hydrogen bonded with Mo2 oxo oxygen O8 (Fig. 6). It also shows H-bonding interaction with O21 of DMF solvent. The other symmetrically equivalent O1Wa (a =-x +1, -y, -z) shows H-bonding interactions with O8 of one metalloligand and O21 of another DMF molecule.
